SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 5 of “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”
:ibox:“But the vividness of memory — its sensation of accuracy — is an i͟l͟l͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n created by that rush of emotion.”
What is the meaning of i͟l͟l͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: a specific feeling

B.Choice: a reference to something

C.Choice: something that can be seen

D.Choice: something that is misleading

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Which statement shows how psychologists played a role in the study of the human nose in “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”?

A.Choice: They determined which sense is the strongest.

B.Choice: They examined the connection of emotion to scents.

C.Choice: They examined all parts of the body including the nose.

D.Choice: They determined which scents prompt certain memories.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 5 in “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”
:ibox:The architecture of the brain explains the Proust phenomenon, Herz thinks.
Why does the author use “architecture” to describe the brain in the sentence?

A.Choice: to compare the brain and designer's purposes

B.Choice: to compare the artistry of brains and buildings

C.Choice: to compare the brain's design to a building's design

D.Choice: to compare the brain's components to a building's components

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Which statement BEST describes how the author develops the central idea that sense of smell is an important part of memory recall in “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”?

A.Choice: by describing experiments scientists have done about memory and smells

B.Choice: by sharing stories about how smells triggered memories for certain people

C.Choice: by illustrating a specific example of how a smell triggered a memory in an individual

D.Choice: by explaining the scientific connection between the human brain and the sense of smell

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: Read the quotation from paragraph 5 of “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”

:ibox:“I believe that the Proust phenomenon can be subtly redefined,” Herz says. “Odors may trigger a memory of uncommon emotional power, it is true. But the vividness of memory—its sensation of accuracy—is an illusion created by that rush of emotion.”
How does the author use the quotation to support her argument in the passage?

A.Choice: to add to the Proust phenomenon experience by stating odors retrieve old memories

B.Choice: to support the Proust phenomenon experience by agreeing that odor retrieves old memories

C.Choice: to modify the Proust phenomenon experience by combining odors and emotions to retrieve old memories

D.Choice: to disprove the Proust phenomenon experience by stating that emotions are what retrieves old memories

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Identify one claim made by the author in “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”

A.Choice: Smells bring back childhood fears.

B.Choice: Smell has a special connection to feelings.

C.Choice: Vision is the most important sense for memory recall.

D.Choice: Findings of past research are incorrect and need to be revised.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The same sights, sounds, and odors that are present when we learn something new help us to recall it later.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Odor cues brought back older memories—things that happened when the respondents were ages 6 to 10.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “Subjects rated their smell­cued memories as more emotional and richer in detail than the word­ or picture-stimulated ones.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “Regardless of whether they had smelled the odor or just heard the word, people were no more accurate in remembering the painting.” (paragraph 4)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Which quotation should be included in an accurate summary of the passage “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!”?

A.Choice: “Talk about instant travel in space and time!” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “In our everyday experience, it seems that nothing jogs the memory better than a smell.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “The researchers gave people tests of facts about the museum, asking what they remembered about their visits...” (paragraph 2)

D.Choice: “Odors are processed and memories are retrieved (but not stored) in the brain's right half.” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: Why does the author include paragraphs 1–6 in the passage “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?”

A.Choice: to describe the research that has been done

B.Choice: to introduce the different scientists that conducted studies

C.Choice: to show that studies from the past have given incorrect information

D.Choice: to share information about the different studies that have been conducted

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does paragraph 8 contribute to the development of the passage “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?”

A.Choice: It introduces a reason for the study.

B.Choice: It gives an example of a central concept.

C.Choice: It provides an example for the phenomenon.

D.Choice: It serves as a transition from the previous paragraph.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing each medium's portrayal of the subject (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words).
Content: What is an advantage of using the photograph of the MRI in “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?” to present information about the sense of smell?

A.Choice: It shows the emotional effect of odors on the brain.

B.Choice: It adds information about how odors reach the brain.

C.Choice: It adds information about the poor sense of smell that humans have.

D.Choice: It shows how the right half of the brain stores information on emotion.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how two or more authors writing about the same topic shape their presentations of key information by emphasizing different evidence or advancing different interpretations of facts.
Content: How do the authors of “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!” and “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?” differ in their emphasis of information on the nose?

A.Choice: In “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!” the author acknowledges a psychological connection, while the author of “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?” exposes failed past inquiries.

B.Choice: In “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!” the author provides an explanation of a phenomenon, while the author of “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?” explains a theory written by Plato.

C.Choice: In “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!” the author describes anecdotes, while the author of “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?” provides data from research and lingering questions.

D.Choice: In “Beam Me Up, Smell­ie!” the author points out the strength of senses, while the author of “Q&A: How Can Our Noses Smell a Trillion Different Odor Mixtures?” provides a detailed description on the future of nasal research.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: How is the point of view of the bird different from the speaker in lines 10–19?

A.Choice: The bird imagines what the speaker thinks, while the speaker wants to get a feather from the bird.

B.Choice: The bird appears fearful of the speaker, while the speaker imagines what the bird is thinking.

C.Choice: The bird does not pay attention to the speaker, while the speaker observes the bird closely.

D.Choice: The bird is careful where he sits, while the speaker seems careless about nature.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choice (e.g., alliteration) on meaning and tone.
Content: Read line 11 from the passage.
:ibox:To put a tree between us when he l͟i͟g͟h͟t͟e͟d,
What is the meaning of l͟i͟g͟h͟t͟e͟d as it is used in the line?

A.Choice: burned

B.Choice: chirped

C.Choice: illuminated

D.Choice: landed

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: What does the speaker imply about the bird when he states “One flight out sideways would have undeceived him” in line 17?

A.Choice: The bird is startled and takes off in flight.

B.Choice: The speaker needs to communicate with the bird.

C.Choice: The bird could approach the speaker to see the truth.

D.Choice: The speaker is really trying to steal a feather as the bird takes flight.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choice (e.g., alliteration) on meaning and tone.
Content: What does the speaker mean in lines 18–19 by saying “there was a pile of wood for which / I forgot him”?

A.Choice: The speaker overlooked the wood.

B.Choice: The speaker stumbled on the wood.

C.Choice: The speaker lost all memory of the wood.

D.Choice: The speaker became distracted by the wood.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the inference that the speaker is curious?

A.Choice: “Out walking in the frozen swamp one grey day” (line 1)

B.Choice: “I paused and said, 'I will turn back from here.'” (line 2)

C.Choice: “'No, I will go on farther—and we shall see.'” (line 3)

D.Choice: “And not another like it could I see.” (line 25)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Which statement is a central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: The speaker is intrigued by natural elements.

B.Choice: The speaker meets the creatures of the woods.

C.Choice: The speaker examines the plant life of the woods.

D.Choice: The speaker struggles with which direction to choose.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a literary text interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What do the woodpile and the bird have in common in the passage?

A.Choice: Both are decaying.

B.Choice: Both are forgotten.

C.Choice: Both are far from home.

D.Choice: Both are covered in snow.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Out walking in the frozen swamp one grey day” (line 1)

B.Choice: “The hard snow held me, save where now and then” (line 4)

C.Choice: “Or somewhere else: I was just far from home.” (line 9)

D.Choice: “Without so much as wishing him good­night.” (line 21)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Read lines 18–20 from the passage.

:ibox:And then there was a pile of wood for which
I forgot him and let his little fear
Carry him off the way I might have gone,
How do these lines from the passage develop a central idea?

A.Choice: by illustrating the fascination that nature holds

B.Choice: by describing the importance of completing a task

C.Choice: by showing that past actions can impact the future

D.Choice: by introducing an example of continuing when it seems  pointless

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choice (e.g., alliteration) on meaning and tone.
Content: Read line 26 from the passage.
:ibox:No runner tracks in this year's snow looped near it.
What can the reader infer about the swamp based on the line?

A.Choice: There is a path surrounding the swamp.

B.Choice: There is a small population in the swamp.

C.Choice: There has not recently been anyone in the swamp.

D.Choice: There has not normally been snowfall in that particular area.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: How does the author's use of the word “burning” in line 40 affect the meaning of the passage?

A.Choice: It compares natural light and light from a fire.

B.Choice: It suggests the speaker wanted to build a campfire.

C.Choice: It creates a contrast between natural decay and fire.

D.Choice: It implies there was a wildfire that destroyed the woodpile.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast a written story, drama, or poem to its audio, filmed, staged, or multimedia version, analyzing the effects of techniques unique to each medium (e.g., lighting, sound, color, or camera focus and angles in a film).
Content: How would the meaning of the passage change if it were written about the photograph?

A.Choice: The mood would be gloomy.

B.Choice: The resolution would happen sooner.

C.Choice: The speaker would no longer feel isolated.

D.Choice: The speaker would have no need for the woodpile.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which sentence is a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Nature is full of mysteries to discover.

B.Choice: Exploration of the world is often rewarding.

C.Choice: Humans have the same motivations as animals.

D.Choice: Inspiration drawn from nature can lead to success.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “He thought that I was after him for a feather—” (line 14)

B.Choice: “The white one in his tail; ...” (line 15)

C.Choice: “And then there was a pile of wood for which / I forgot him...” (lines 18–19)

D.Choice: “... and let his little fear / Carry him off the way I might have gone,” (lines 19–20)

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: Which word means the same as a͟c͟c͟o͟m͟m͟o͟d͟a͟t͟i͟o͟n͟s as it is used in paragraph 1?

A.Choice: contents

B.Choice: lodgings

C.Choice: offices

D.Choice: positions

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which statement is a central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: Paddlewheel steamboats are modern examples of history.

B.Choice: Paddlewheel steamboats are rapidly replacing the more luxurious cruises.

C.Choice: Paddlewheel steamboats offer travelers a glimpse of the life of Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer.

D.Choice: Paddlewheel steamboats require several crew members and more expensive technology than in previous years.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... like the passengers of more than a century ago, today's travelers view spectacular scenery.” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “'A lot of the river that our passengers see remains the same as it did 200 or 300 years ago,' ...” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “During World War II, the Navy used the boat to ferry troops around San Francisco Bay.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “The riverlorian points out unusual bits of history along the boat's course, gives onboard talks, and arranges games and other fun pursuits for children.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.

:ibox:It features the world's largest steam­powered c͟a͟l͟l͟i͟o͟p͟e. (paragraph 6)

Steamboat passengers enjoy onboard activities like c͟a͟l͟l͟i͟o͟p͟e concerts, kite flying, cooking demonstrations, movies, games, and craft lessons. (paragraph 12)
Based on the contexts in both sentences, what is the meaning of c͟a͟l͟l͟i͟o͟p͟e?

A.Choice: a paddlewheel

B.Choice: a type of singing

C.Choice: a musical instrument

D.Choice: a telescope for sightseeing

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How do paragraphs 6–8 contribute to the development of ideas in the passage?

A.Choice: by showing that modern steamboats are larger and more complex than the steamboats of history, but that they are still powered by steam engines

B.Choice: by showing that modern steamboats are different from the steamboats of history because they have newer, gasoline­powered engines and more safety features

C.Choice: by showing that modern steamboats are exactly like the steamboats of history in every way possible, and that they stop along the river like the old steamboats did

D.Choice: by showing that modern steamboats are similar to the steamboats of history, but that modern steamboats do not stop at places on the river like the old steamboats did

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text (e.g., how ideas influence individuals or events, or how individuals influence ideas or events).
Content: According to the passage, which TWO aspects of modern steamboat travel are similar to those experienced by Victorian­era travelers?

A.Choice: the use of paddle wheels

B.Choice: the methods of navigation

C.Choice: the necessity for large crews

D.Choice: the number of industrial towns

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Which word could replace o͟l͟d͟-͟t͟i͟m͟e͟r͟s in paragraph 10 while retaining the informal language?

A.Choice: employees

B.Choice: experts

C.Choice: predecessors

D.Choice: seniors

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What claim does the author make?

A.Choice: Steamboat travel is not an activity that everyone could enjoy.

B.Choice: Steamboat travel is basically the same as it was over a century ago.

C.Choice: Steamboat travel is going to become even more popular in the future.

D.Choice: Steamboat travel can be fun and entertaining for many different types of people.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The steamboat company offers 3­ to 11­night cruises along the Mississippi, Ohio, Cumberland, and other rivers in the southern and midwestern United States.” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “At many landings, deck hands still hop off to tie the boats' lines to trees or cables on the riverbanks.” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “Maloy has traveled up and down almost all of the company's routes, doing research and talking with old-timers in each town.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “Steamboat passengers enjoy onboard activities like calliope concerts, kite flying, cooking demonstrations, movies, games, and craft lessons.” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choice (e.g., alliteration) on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 1.
:ibox:“That old n͟u͟i͟s͟a͟n͟c͟e of a Rachel Lynde was here again today, pestering me for a subscription towards buying a carpet for the vestry room,” said Mr. Harrison wrathfully.
What is the meaning of n͟u͟i͟s͟a͟n͟c͟e as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: a nosy person

B.Choice: an irritating person

C.Choice: a respectful person

D.Choice: an intelligent person

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a literary text interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 1.
:ibox:“She can put a whole sermon, text, comment, and application, into six words, and throw it at you like a brick.”
How does the sentence impact the plot of the passage?

A.Choice: It defines the problem Mrs. Lynde faced.

B.Choice: It describes the conflict between Mrs. Lynde and Anne.

C.Choice: It shows how the other characters are affected by Mrs. Lynde.

D.Choice: It explains how Mr. Harrison and Anne come to a resolution over Mrs. Lynde.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a literary text interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: How does paragraph 2 define Anne's character?

A.Choice: by showing how the setting is reflected in her personality

B.Choice: by describing how the setting of the story impacts her life

C.Choice: by contrasting Anne's viewpoint with her father's viewpoint

D.Choice: by implying that Anne is more concerned with her surroundings than with her father

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: What does Mr. Harrison imply by calling Mrs. Lynde “an acquired taste” in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: Mrs. Lynde reminds Mr. Harrison of things he dislikes.

B.Choice: Mrs. Lynde involves herself in other people's business.

C.Choice: Mr. Harrison may learn to like Mrs. Lynde if he gets to know her.

D.Choice: Mr. Harrison refuses to be around Mrs. Lynde because of his dislike for her.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 12.
:ibox:“I suppose she has some good qualities,” conceded Mr. Harrison g͟r͟u͟d͟g͟i͟n͟g͟l͟y.
What word means the same as g͟r͟u͟d͟g͟i͟n͟g͟l͟y as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: disrespectfully

B.Choice: gratefully

C.Choice: suspiciously

D.Choice: unwillingly

Content: Which word from paragraph 12 helps define g͟r͟u͟d͟g͟i͟n͟g͟l͟y as it is used in the sentence in Part A?

A.Choice: qualities

B.Choice: conceded

C.Choice: never

D.Choice: suspect

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: Which paragraphs from the passage represent the contrasting points of view of Mr. Harrison and Anne?

A.Choice: paragraphs 1 and 2

B.Choice: paragraphs 3 and 4

C.Choice: paragraphs 7 and 8

D.Choice: paragraphs 9 and 10

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Based on the passage, what can be inferred about Anne's feelings toward Mrs. Lynde?

A.Choice: Anne feels adoration for Mrs. Lynde.

B.Choice: Anne feels compassion for Mrs. Lynde.

C.Choice: Anne feels scornful toward Mrs. Lynde.

D.Choice: Anne feels resentful toward Mrs. Lynde.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'I detest that woman more than anybody I know.'” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “'I didn't like Mrs. Lynde at first either; but as soon as I came to understand her I learned to.'” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “'... I understand that she is a confirmed busybody and I told her so.'” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “'And as for Mrs. Lynde being a busybody, perhaps she zis.'” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which quotation from Mr. Harrison suggests he agrees with Anne about Rachel Lynde?

A.Choice: “'Mrs. Lynde may be an acquired taste with some folks; ...'” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “'And as for understanding her, I understand that she is a confirmed busybody and I told her so.'” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “'It was the truth and I believe in telling the truth to everybody.'” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “'Well, well, I'll try and not mention it again since you're so sensitive.'” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What is a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Always speaking the truth is impolite.

B.Choice: People's opinions are not easily changed.

C.Choice: Gossiping about others can lead to hurt feelings.

D.Choice: People should strive to see the good characteristics in others.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'It was the truth and I believe in telling the truth to everybody.'” (paragraph 6)

B.Choice: “'You only tell the disagreeable part of the truth.'” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “'Well, well, I'll try and not mention it again since you're so sensitive.'” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “'I've got a habit of being outspoken and folks mustn't mind it.'” (paragraph 10)

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: How do paragraphs 1–3 support the author's purpose?

A.Choice: The paragraphs describe a scientist's interest in studying ocean life.

B.Choice: The paragraphs introduce a scientist as well as the topic of the interview.

C.Choice: The paragraphs pose several questions that are answered later in the passage.

D.Choice: The paragraphs indicate reasons why the reader may be interested in the topic.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:You get a sense that these animals not only know where they are but they know where they're going in this big ocean.
What additional quotation supports the inference that the author makes in the sentence?

A.Choice: “But animals see it very differently, and that's why it's useful to send fleets of animals out with tags on them.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “By combining tag data with oceanographic data, we get to see how animals perceive the ocean, ...” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Sometimes they'll get into an eddy, which is a big circulation pattern that can be 100 km across, ...” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “They get pushed around by strong currents, but then they'll travel back to resume their trajectory.” (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: In paragraph 2, Jeff Polovina states, “'The tags allow us to see tracks in the ocean.'” Which quotation from the passage supports the statement?

A.Choice: “We look out on the ocean and see this homogenous expanse.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “They're following well­defined paths.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “That front separates a nutrient­rich mass of water to the north from nutrient­poor waters to the south, ...” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “... we used to think that whale sharks mainly used the shallow surface layer of the ocean.” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:They get pushed around by strong currents, but then they'll travel back t͟o͟ ͟r͟e͟s͟u͟m͟e͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟i͟r͟ ͟t͟r͟a͟j͟e͟c͟t͟o͟r͟y.
What is the meaning of the phrase t͟o͟ ͟r͟e͟s͟u͟m͟e͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟i͟r͟ ͟t͟r͟a͟j͟e͟c͟t͟o͟r͟y as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: to travel off course

B.Choice: to become lost in the ocean

C.Choice: to arrive at a specific location

D.Choice: to continue on the same path

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What does the author's use of “shoot” in paragraph 17 illustrate about the fish?

A.Choice: It explains the different depths in which the fish forage in their search for food.

B.Choice: It indicates the speed at which the fish move from one depth of the water to another.

C.Choice: It shows that moving from one depth to another while looking for food is dangerous for the fish.

D.Choice: It demonstrates that the fish are releasing food as they move between different depths of the water.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 18.

:ibox:Different species seem to be p͟a͟r͟t͟i͟t͟i͟o͟n͟i͟n͟g the vertical depth structure in the ocean, each foraging on different species in a different depth range, so that they're not all at the same depth competing for the same resources.
What is the meaning of p͟a͟r͟t͟i͟t͟i͟o͟n͟i͟n͟g as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: defining

B.Choice: hiding

C.Choice: layering

D.Choice: registering

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does the author's use of the interview format aid in the understanding of the passage?

A.Choice: It allows the author to introduce various types of sea life and talk about their habitats.

B.Choice: It offers a clear understanding of the relationship between sea creatures and humans.

C.Choice: It provides steps that the reader can take in order to conduct research about ocean life.

D.Choice: It introduces an expert who gives examples of how animal tagging and satellite imaging lead to discoveries.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: What is the author's point of view about tagging different species of ocean animals for data?

A.Choice: The author disapproves of the tags because they cannot track different species effectively.

B.Choice: The author approves of the tags because he believes it is important to help conserve the different species.

C.Choice: The author disapproves of the tags because they provide false information on the swimming patterns of different species.

D.Choice: The author approves of the tags because he assists with the research and has already tagged hundreds of different species.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing each medium's portrayal of the subject (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words).
Content: How does the photograph help develop an understanding of the satellite tags?

A.Choice: It shows how satellite tags are attached to animals.

B.Choice: It shows the effects of smaller satellite tags on smaller animals.

C.Choice: It shows where satellite tags are located on the loggerhead sea turtles.

D.Choice: It shows how satellite tags affect where loggerhead sea turtle migrate.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What did scientists learn after tagging loggerhead turtles on the beaches of Japan?

A.Choice: There were 400 loggerhead turtles on the beach.

B.Choice: Most of the Pacific Ocean had never been studied.

C.Choice: Loggerheads migrate after hatching on Japanese beaches.

D.Choice: There was an important feature of the ocean that was not known before.

Content: What effect would the information in the answer to Part A have on future scientific investigations?

A.Choice: Scientists will not explore that section of ocean anymore.

B.Choice: Scientists will decide that turtles are no longer endangered.

C.Choice: Scientists will look even more closely for unexpected results.

D.Choice: Scientists will assume all ocean animals migrate right after birth.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: What is a central idea of “Satellite Tagging”?

A.Choice: Scientists are constantly developing new ways to study animal habitats.

B.Choice: Scientists tag ocean animals to analyze the causes of certain migration patterns.

C.Choice: Scientists use satellites to create images of the ocean floor to learn about animal habitats.

D.Choice: Scientists utilize electronic tags and satellite images to learn how to better protect ocean species.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: Read the following prompt and write your complete response in the space provided.

:ibox:You have read “Clover,” a passage about a man named Graham. Write an essay describing Graham's interactions with his students. Analyze how the author describes Graham's unique characteristics in the classroom and at home and how the students react to him. Provide key details and examples from the passage to support your response.

Your writing will be scored based on the development of ideas, organization of writing, and language conventions of grammar, usage, and mechanics.
Write your response for the prompt on the lines below.
